This test uses tokenized sources, and therefore ignores whitespace, comments, and identifier names when comparing source-code. It is very robust to a wide range of other manipulations, and is therefore used as a default test.
This test compares the size of compressing the sources of each submission separately vs. compressing both together, using Zip as a compressor. See the wikipedia article on NCD for more details.

Submissions that have the same distribution of tokens are more similar than those that do not.

This test uses tokenized sources, and therefore ignores whitespace, comments, and identifier names when comparing source-code. It is also immune to code refactoring that does not change the total amounts of each type of token.

This test calculates the scalar product of the normalized token-vectors for two submissions. It is based on the cosine similarity test used in information retrieval. See the wikipedia article on cosine-similarity for more details.
